characters: A SLIP OF PAPER THAT SAYS "SYDNEY"

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: As the OPENING TTTLES ROLL against a series of shots of statues and paintings of former presidents, we HEAR shard dialogue from various presidential speeches.

dialogues.speaker: THE WHITE HOUSE
dialogues.text: It's an early November morning, and the sun has just come over this extraordinary building. WE HOLD on this for a m before we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SECRET SERVICE AGENT presses the button by the private elevator as he talks into his shirt cuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liberty's moving. Another AGENT rounds the corner into the corridor and is followed a step or two later by PRESIDENT ANDREW BENJAMIN SHEPHERD. SHEPHERD's walking with his personal assistant, JANIE, a professional and incredibly efficient 25-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 10:15 event's been moved inside to the Indian Treaty Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Janie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 10:15 is American Fisheries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. They're giving you a 200-pound halibut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie, make a note. We need to schedule more events where somebody gives me a really big fish. JANIE starts to make a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie, I was kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the AGENT at the elevator)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Cooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Mr. President. SHEPHERD and JANIE enter the elevator. As the doors close

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Rothschild asked to have a moment with you this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he upset about the speech last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seemed concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it wouldn't be a Monday morning unless Lewis was concerned about something I did Sunday night. The elevator doors open, revealing LEWIS ROTHSCHILD. At 3 LEWIS is the President's chief domestic policy advisor. I would appear that he averages about two hours sleep a nig though that doesn't seem to slow him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You skipped the whole paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Janie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Monday morning it is. LEWIS falls into the pace as the three of them head for t double doors leading to the South Lawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "American can no longer afford to pretend that they live in a great society"...and then nothing. You dumped the whole handguns paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a time for prudence, Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the kick-ass section. The three of them are now OUTSIDE and making their way do the COVERED WALKWAY that runs from the East Wing to the W Wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought what with being the President and all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, of course I didn't mean to imply--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be turning cartwheels this morning, Lewis -- 63 percent job approval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great news, sir, but... They walk past a GROUNDKEEPER who's at work at a patch of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Mr. President. Before he's even completed the last syllable of the greet JANIE quickly and quietly said--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Morning, Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, the press is gonna need an explanation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what? SHEPHERD, LEWIS and JANIE walk through the door being hel open by an AGENT. The conversation continues as they make their way through the corridors of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk quickly down a hallway teeming with STAFFERS, A AND OFFICE WORKERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you dropped the whole kick-ass section, now we've got this thing hanging out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a thing hanging out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Americans can no longer afford to pretend that they live in a great society." Then ...nothing. No explanation. No context. So now it's just this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's hanging out there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. SHEPHERD stops at an open doorway, calls to a STAFFER--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they tell you I'm gonna need--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --overall consumer spending and not just first homes. Yes, sir. We'll have it for you in 15 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. SHEPHERD moves on. LEWIS and JANIE stay with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I really feel we need to focus on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, however much coffee you drink in the morning, I want you to reduce it by half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't drink coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then hit yourself over the head with a baseball bat, would you please? Another STAFFER crosses their path--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday, Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Laura, happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. Once out of earshot--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JANIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should send her some flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You already did, sir. And, with that, they walk through a doorway and into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the OUTER OFFICE, MRS. CHAPIL, the President's secreta is hard at work on a word processor. She stands as SHEPHE walks in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you, Mrs. Chapil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, thank you, sir. Mr. Kodak left the detailed breakdown of the approval poll for you. He seemed to indicate that it was very good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-three percent of it, at any rate. And by now they're in the OVAL OFFICE itself. SHEPHERD ha gone to his desk and is looking over the various overnigh briefing memos that have been left for him. As someone us to doing six things at once, he has no trouble reading, listening, and talking at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy called just a moment ago. You forgot to sign her permission slip for her class--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the museum trip. I'll go get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JANIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time does she get home today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three-twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's my afternoon look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very crowded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schedule some time for me at 3:30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buenos dias, Senor Presidente. This from ROBIN McCALL, a strikingly tall black woman and President's press secretary, as she strides into the room

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too-tall McCall, how was Mexico?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't truly appreciate it until I came back and discovered that America isn't a great society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to ROBIN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He dumped a whole section.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's a thing hanging out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a great society, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, with you out of the country, it wasn't, Robin. Now that you're back, we're great again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a press room full of people saying "What did he mean by that?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: a memo he's been looking at)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.J., did you get one of these? This is said to A. J. MACINERNEY as he walks through a separate entrance on the left side of the room. In additi to being the President's Chief of Staff and closest advis he's the President's closest and oldest friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the letter from Solomon at the GDC?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would appear to be a letter from the entire environmental community. These people are outta control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they're just frustrated, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they blaming the President for global warming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they don't think he caused it, if that's what you mean. (continuing; to SHEPHERD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm on the phone with these people twice a week. I honestly don't know what they want at this point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What they want is a 20 percent reduction in fossil fuel emissions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't pass at 20 percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We haven't really tried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, McSorley, McCluskey and Shane hold too many markers. If we try to push this through and lose, there will be a very loud thud when we hit the ground, and that's not what you want in an election year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to the GDC again, A.J. Tell them the President resents the implication that he's turned his back on the environment. Tell them I'll send 455 to the floor. But we're gonna ask for a 10 percent reduction. If they want to pull their support, fine. At 63 percent job approval rating. I don't need their help getting a bill passed. We gotta get going-- where's Leon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to an AIDE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you call Mr. Kodak and tell him the President's-- A.J.'s sentence is cut short by the sound of a head-on pedestrian collision in the outer office--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aaagh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry! Sorry, my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the AIDE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind. LEON KODAK comes into the oval office. The White House pollster is a likable, if clumsy, numbers whiz. He, along with A.J., LEWIS, and ROBIN, are regarded as the Presiden Starting Team. The people in this room have grown very cl over the past few years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Good morning, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They keep moving that big ficus plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all here, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. First, I wanted to say congratulations. Three years ago, we were elected to the White House by one of the narrowest margins in history, and today Kodak tells us 63 percent of registered voters think we're doing a good job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second. You wanted me to poll registered voters? Everyone LAUGHS... even SHEPHERD smiles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the poll also tells us what we already knew: We don't get this crime bill of ours through Congress and these numbers are gonna be a memory. So, starting today, we're shifting it into gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I tell my morning press gaggle that gun control--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crime control, Robin. Gun control means we're wimps and we're soft on crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on, are we not--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we not putting back the handgun restrictions?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're leaving 'em out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we campaigned on this issue. Now, I understand we took it out when we were in the low forties, but we can push it through now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the elections.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, we may never have an opportunity like this again. Let's take this 63 percent out for a spin and see what it can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't take it out for a spin, Lewis. We need it to get re-elected. For reasons passing understanding, people do not relate guns to gun-related crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin, you can brief the press this afternoon. As of today, the crime bill's priority one on the President's domestic agenda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon, you're gonna run the war room. We're gonna need detailed projections for all the target districts by the end of the week. And, Leon, don't be a nice, sweet guy from Brooklyn. Do what the N.R.A. does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scare the shit out of 'em?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, we want you to be legislative liaison on this. You're gonna run the show on the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I just say, to return to the subject for one moment, that it might be easier to fight a war on drugs if we weren't arming drug dealers. SHEPHERD responds a little too quickly -- we see a spark temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, we've gotta fight the fights we can win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to announce the crime bill at the State of the Union, which is 72 days from today. The last nose count put us 18 votes short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighteen votes in 72 days. Thank you, everyone. Janie, what's next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. President. The meeting's over. LEWIS, ROBIN, and KODAK say their "Th you, Mr. President"'s as they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Security briefing, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's around 10 o'clock the same morning as the capital di in its own way, is showing signs of the approaching Thank and Christmas holidays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the seventh floor of the building. A RECEPTIONIST tell where we are by answering the phone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Global Defense Council...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got off the phone with A.J. MacInerney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEO, a white-haired man in his early 60's is meeting with SUSAN SLOAN, a 40'ish lawyer who seems to go out of her w to create an issue where none exists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the President read the letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's pissed as hell, Susan. That letter was a stupid move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was aggressive, and we should stand by every--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't the guy who needed us four years ago, Susan. He's incredibly popular. He's gonna win re-election in a walk, and he could give a shit what we stand by! If the President passes the most important piece of environmental legislation in history, and does it despite our negative endorsement, our political weight in the future will rank somewhere below the Save the Spotted Owl Society. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm bringing in some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need another environmental expert to confirm what every other environmental expert--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not an environmental expert, a professional political strategist. We're playing hardball with Andrew Shepherd, and we need a heavy bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney Ellen Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Christ. That woman doesn't know the first thing about the environmental lobby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a closer, Susan. She gets the job done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD and LEWIS -- working on a speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try it like this and lose that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David Sasser from the Times called and wanted to know what the White House felt was a great society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you tell him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told him I couldn't speak for the President, but for my money: Bermuda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect. JANIE steps in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, your cousin Judith's come down with the flu and won't be able to join you Thursday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad. Remind me to give her a call later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna go stag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We've never gone wrong parading you around as the lonely widower. The words came out casually, but they instantly freeze ev

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe I said that. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, that was an incredibly thoughtless remark. I would never dream of insulting you or the memory of your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay, forget it. (to JANIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 3:45, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go over and say hi to Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have the Attorney General at 4:00 and the trade representative at 4:30. Somewhere in there you promised NPR five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin, don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We HEAR the sound of a TROMBONE being played--not well--f one of the rooms. SHEPHERD comes around and down the corr He walks into--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LUCY, Shepherd's 12-year-old daughter, stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, keep going. I liked what you were playing? What's it called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you play it with gusto!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are my lips swollen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they supposed to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're doing fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha got behind your back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a dirt bike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. He hands her an old textbook ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it a really old seventh-grade textbook of yours that you're gonna make me read cover to cover and discuss at dinner and drive me crazy with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not comfortable with the "really old" part, but everything else you said was true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading the cover)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Understanding the Constitution."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your social studies teacher said your class would be starting on the Constitution this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talked to Mr. Linder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It's called a Parent-Teacher Conference. Mr. Linder and I were the key player in that discussion. Why don't you like social studies, Luce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it fine, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All your other teachers say you're happy, you're enthusiastic, you've always got your hand up...Mr. Linder says you don't participate unless he calls on you, and even then it's a one-word answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say, Dad. I guess I'm just not...I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luce, take a look at this book. This is exciting stuff. It's about who we are and what we want. Read what it says on the first page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Property of Gilmore Junior High School."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "We, the People, of the United States, in order to form a more perfect union..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See? Grabs you right off the bat. It's a page-turner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, 'cause it's possible the subject might come up at dinner tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see it as part of your job to torture me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just one of the perks. See you tonight. He gives her a kiss on the head and heads out the door. Behind him, he hears Lucy's rendition of "Hail to the Chi SHEPHERD shoots her a look as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where SHEPHERD is finishing a meeting with the DEFENSE SECRETARY, CHAIRMAN OF THE JOINT CHIEFS and a NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISOR, each of whom is accompanied by at least DEPUTY or AIDE. A.J. is also present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The C-STAD hardware's been in place for a month. We've got 22 instructors from the Army Air Defense School waiting to go down and train the Israelis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon can you deploy them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can airlift 'em in the morning. They'll have C-STAD operational in 20 days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any security concerns?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If anybody wanted to hit it, they'd have hit it by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's move on it. Thank you, gentlemen. SHEPHERD and A.J. leave the Cabinet Room amidst a volley "good-bye" 's and "Thank you, Mr. President"'s. They pass MRS. CHAPIL and JANIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good evening, Mrs. Chapil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too, Mr. President. SHEPHERD starts his walk from the West Wing back to the residence. It is the exact reverse of the path he took to the OVAL O in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you in the morning, Janie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will, Mr. President. A SECRET SERVICE AGENT follows at a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liberty is moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Solomon brought in a hired gun at the GDC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a lawyer from Virginia named Sydney Ellen Wade. I know this woman well. She's had a lot of success getting congressmen elected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we should try to steal her. Ten percent, A.J. Don't let them leave the room till they're clear about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, if you've got a free second, maybe you could stop in and say hello. It might smooth the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mention it to Janie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let's clear this off the table and get everybody focused on the crime bill. I don't want to win this. I want to win it by a couple of touchdowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will, Mr. President. SHEPHERD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. A.J. starts to leave. SHEPHERD stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Robin said something to me today that I'm sure she wouldn't have said it if...I mean, she wasn't saying it to me, I realize... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, never mind. Have a good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.J., when we're out of the office and we're alone, you can call me Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean you were the best man at my wedding, for crying out loud. Call me Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughing off the suggestion)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever you say, Mr. President. They have reached the south entrance to the White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good night, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, A.J. SHEPHERD enters the White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's early morning of the following day, and the grounds outside are in full swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of the guardhouse, Susan and her new colleague, SYDNEY ELLEN WADE, are being cleared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the GUARD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, my name's Sydney Ellen Wade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just needs your driver's license. SUSAN hands the guard her license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (handing him her license)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the GUARD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for a meeting with Mr. MacInerney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't need to know that. The GUARD BUZZES her through the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the GUARD)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, this is my first time at the White House. I'm trying to savor the Capra-esque quality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know what Capra-esque means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SUSAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I do. Frank Capra, great American director -- It's a Wonderful Life, Mr. Smith Goes to Washington. (handing SYDNEY and SUSAN their laminated passes)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney Ellen Wade of Virginia. Knock 'em dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. SYDNEY and SUSAN begin to walk up the path toward the ent to the West Wing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meeting with the EDUCATION SECRETARY, the HUD SECRETARY several AIDES and LEWIS is breaking up. SHEPHERD is usher people out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day the government starts subsidizing private schools is the day we give up on public education. EDUCATION SECRETARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the proposal only scratches the surface, but it's the least we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're already doing the least we can do, but I can't think of anything better, so we'll go with this for now. (to HUD SECRETARY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jerry, say hello to Linda for me. And if I don't see you again, have a good Thanksgiving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr. President. The room has cleared...JANIE is arranging new papers on t President's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're we doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're running four minutes ahead of schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ahead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie, this is unprecedented. I don't know what to do with myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. MacInerney asked me to remind you to pop your head in on--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GDC meeting. Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. A.J.'s OFFICE - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your concerns are not falling on deaf ears. The environmental lobby has known no greater alley in the White House than President Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hardly an impressive distinction, A.J. SUSAN is trying to avert the inevitable--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, we should leave Mr. MacInerney alone now. He's already given us more time than--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, Mr. MacInerney doesn't want us to leave, because Mr. MacInerney's not yet done what he needs to do today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Ms. Wade's been thrown into the deep end of the pool on her first day. She hasn't even had a chance to read the report of the Quebec Conference. SYDNEY -- whose brain is telling her to slam on the brake check her swing, smile and leave the building -- decides, instead, to hit the gas and swing away. The OTHERS are wa this as if they were watching the evolution of a train wr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I haven't read it. If someone had asked me yesterday, I'd have told them the Quebec Conference was made up of six professional hockey teams. But what I do know is that it's time for the President to run for president again. Leon Kodak is as good as it gets when it comes to electoral strategy, and I'm certain he's told the President exactly what I'd tell him: Nail down Michigan and California, where they make cars and airplanes -- and burn plenty of fossil fuel. But if I had read these eight hundred pages, I would have discovered that it's the burning of fossil fuels that's been mostly responsible for global warming and that the 20 percent reduction recommended by the GDC is a necessary first step toward arresting the catastrophic greenhouse effect that has gone unchecked by this administration...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SYDNEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really time to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan, I promise you, the White House Chief of Staff will not let us leave here until he's broken the bad news. No one in the room really understands what's going on... except A.J., who would like to take the time to admire SYDNEY but, of course, can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid Sydney's right. Although not about Michigan and California. The President has asked me to convey to you that he's sending his energy bill to the floor with a call for a reduction of 10 percent. There's an uncomfortable silence in the room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President is willing to go it alone on this, but he's asking for, and frankly he's expecting, the full support of the GDC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's expecting our full support?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's dreamin', A.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --the President has critically misjudged reality. If he honestly thinks that the environmental community is going to whistle a happy tune while rallying support around this pitifully lame mockery of environmental leadership just because he's a nice guy and he's done better than his predecessors, then your boss is the Chief Executive of Fantasyland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take him out back and beat the shit out of him. SYDNEY's blown out her speakers because she's turned in t direction of the private office entrance to see, live and person, The President of the United States. She is frozen. Mortified. If she were capable of thought process, she would be preying for something heavy to fall her head right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. President. How are you today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't be better. (to the GROUP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for the interruption, but A.J. asked me to stop and say hello. You wouldn't be Sydney Ellen Wade, by any chance, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I'm...don't know what to say. I'm speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All evidence to the contrary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we haven't met. My name is Susan Sloan. I used to work with Congressman Myers. I hope this episode in no way--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. SYDNEY gets up to leave. SHEPHERD escorts her out of A.J. office and into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought maybe we might have a word in private. Someplace a little less intimidating. (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SYDNEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my personal assistant, Janie Basdin. Janie, would you show Ms. Wade into the rec room. I'll be there in a second. SHEPHERD enters a doorway off of the hall. SYDNEY continu down the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SYDNEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way... JANIE leads SYDNEY into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...where SYDNEY just stands uncomfortably, not knowing whether to sit or stand. Waiting. Trying -- the way a jum on a window ledge tries not to look down -- trying not to notice things like the JFK Desk, the Seal of the Presiden the United States, the bust of Lincoln... SHEPHERD strides in--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to keep you waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it okay if I call you Sydney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Mr. President--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever been in the Oval Office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been on the regular tour. It didn't include...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear it's pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, what you saw in there was nothing more than vanity run amok. I was showing off for a colleague who doesn't think very much of me. It'd be a real injustice for you to hold the GDC accountable for my behavior today. On top of which, I'm monumentally sorry for having insulted you like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you under the impression that I'm mad at you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, seldom does a day go by that I'm not burned in effigy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not by a professional political operative standing 30 feet from the Oval Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'll give you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know that when the City Planners sat down to design Washington, D.C., their intention was to build a city that would intimidate and humble foreign heads of state? It's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The White House has the single greatest home court advantage in the modern world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learned that one the hard way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, this bill is important to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, I'll convey your message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GDC is asking for 20 percent, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not gonna pass at 20 percent. It's a long shot at 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know that until you put the full weight of the White House behind--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, at 20 percent, we are 34 votes shy in the House. It can't be done. But I tell you what. I'll make you a deal with you. If you can get 24 votes, I'll get you the last 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-four votes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you can swing 24 votes by the State of the Union, I'll promise you full White House support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I have your word on that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Listen, are you hungry? I skipped breakfast. You wanna have some coffee? A donut or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I'm a little intimidated by my surroundings, and yes, I've gotten off to a rocky and somewhat stilted beginning, but don't let that diminish the weight of my message: The GDC has been at every president for the last decade and a half that global warming is a calamity, the effects of which will be second only to nuclear war. The best scientists in the world have given you every reason to take the GDC seriously. But I'm gonna give you one more. If you don't live up to the deal you just made, come New Hampshire, we're gonna go shopping for a new candidate. SYDNEY heads for the door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that, Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all due respect, Mr. President, who's gonna stop me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you go through that door, the United States Secret Service. That's my private office. (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to go out that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. SYDNEY, with as much dignity as she can muster, leaves th Oval Office. SHEPHERD muses about what has just transpire

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD has converted one of the rooms on the second flo residence. His expert shot demonstrates that playing pool something he does almost as well as being President. A.J. stands to the side with his pool cue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: McSorley, McCluskey and Shane know we're making our move on the crime bill. They're circling the wagons on the assault weapons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I meet with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let Lewis take a pass at them first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. 2 in the side. SHEPHERD sends the two-ball flying into the corner pocket

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice shot, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice shot, Mr. President? You won't call me by my name when we're playing pool. A.J. assesses the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will not do it playing pool, I will not do it in a school, I do not like green eggs and ham, I do not like them Sam I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ease, A.J., and get away from the pocket. 9 in the corner. SHEPHERD makes the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Solomon phoned. He said he was thrilled with the deal you made this morning. SHEPHERD lifts his cue for a moment...trying to think it there was something he was supposed to tell A.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I forgot to tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a waste of time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not our time. GDC makes a big push for the votes, and when they come up short, we move in with the softer bill, to get passed, we're everybody's hero. 3 in the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Also, Sydney Wade called. SHEPHERD, a hair too excited by this news, misses by a mi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wanted to apologize one more time for her behavior. 3 in the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she say anything about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did she say anything about you? 13 in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just that we had a nice couple of minutes together. She threatened me and I patronized her and we didn't have anything to eat, but I thought there was a connection. A.J. is staring at him in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't say anything about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no, but I could pass her a note before study hall and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me this: Hypothetically, what would happen--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel a nightmare coming on. 1 in the corner. He misses the shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --if I called Sydney and asked her to be my date at the State Dinner Thursday night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I sound serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President can't just go out on a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Jefferson did. Wilson did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilson was widowed during his first term. He meets a woman named Edith Gault. He dated her, courted her, married her, and somewhere in there managed to form the League of Nations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, this is an election year. If you're looking for female companionship, we can make arrangements that'll insure total privacy and--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you to get me a girl, A.J. What is this, Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, this is the White House.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm talking about something that in no way is at conflict with my oath of office. I'm a single adult, and I met a woman that I'd like to see again socially. How's that different from what Wilson did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The difference is he didn't have to be the president on television. You've said it a million times: If there were a television set in every living room 60 years ago, this country does not elect a man in a wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take a hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How big?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Five points. Maybe more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five points we're standing here talking about?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drop five points when Wisconsin doesn't make it to the Rose Bowl. 5 in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to have Kodak put together some numbers so we know what we're talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. I don't want to check a polling sample to see if this is okay, like I'm asking permission to stay out an hour past curfew. This isn't the business of the American people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, the American people have a funny way of deciding on their own what is and what is not their business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like her, A.J. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop being my chief of staff for one minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie! (to A.J.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't say anything about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said you're taller than she thought you'd be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's something. JANIE enters--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to track down a phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lined with red-brick, three-story walk-ups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few suitcases and two or three moving cartons serve as evidence that SYDNEY's staying with her sister BETH temporarily. BETH, still in hospital scrubs from a 12-hour shift, open bottle of wine while SYDNEY, in a bathrobe and wet hair, tries to get off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard...Richard, it wasn't funny. I acted like a college freshman at a protest rally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him the part about walking out the wrong door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God, I forgot about that. (back into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Richard...Richard, I don't want to hear your Andrew Shepherd imitation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanna hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm hanging up now, Richard... Tonight? I was gonna go to bed early and wake up when there's a new president. She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President must think I'm a third- rate jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he thinks you're a jerk, I'm sure he thinks you're a first-rate jerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you one thing, boy. I regrouped, you gotta gimme that. I pulled it together at the end. I stood in the middle of the Oval Office and I made it very clear that from now on, he who doesn't take the GDC seriously does so at his peril!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then you walked out the wrong door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna be throwing that back at me the rest of my life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my current plan, yes. The TELEPHONE RINGS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's gonna be Leo Solomon. He said he'd call at nine. SYDNEY picks up the phone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, hi, is this Sydney? SYDNEY doesn't recognize the voice--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is Andrew Shepherd. SYDNEY looks at BETH and rolls her eyes, then explains to her--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andrew Shepherd. (back in the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're hilarious, Richard. You're a regular riot. And we CROSS-CUT between SYDNEY and SHEPHERD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh...this isn't Richard, it's Andrew Shepherd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really. Well, I'm so glad you called, because I forgot to tell you today what a nice ass you have. I'm also impressed that you were able to get my phone number, considering I don't have a phone. Good night, Richard. SYDNEY hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as SHEPHERD, undaunted, dials the number again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This used to be easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the PHONE RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to deal with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. I may choke in front of Shepherd, but Richard Reynolds I can handle. She picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? And we begin CROSS-CUTTING again between the two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you learning-impaired?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, do me a favor. Hang up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang up the phone. Then dial 456-1414. When you get the White House operator, give her your name and tell her you want to speak to the President. SHEPHERD hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY's still holding the phone and seems a little confused...an emotion which is about to be replaced by ho as the unbelievable into the reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't happening to me. She dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to herself)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not possible I did this twice in one day. The OPERATOR answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, the White House. SYDNEY swallows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; filtered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Sydney Ellen Wade. I'd like to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's expecting your call, ma'am. I'll put you right through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just opened a bottle of beer when the phone rings. He picks up the phone--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I'm sure there's an appropriate thing to say at this moment. Probably some formal apology for the nice-ass remark would be in order. I just don't quite know how to word it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my fault. I shouldn't have called you at home. Should I call you at the office tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir, of course not. I mean -- yes, you can call me anytime you want -- this is fine. Right now is fine. When I said "of course not," I meat that...You know what? The hell with it -- I'm moving to another country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you mean when you said you don't have a phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just moved to Washington over the weekend, and my apartment isn't ready yet. This is my sister's apartment. Come to think of it, how did you get this number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did I get the number. That's a reasonable question. I don't know. Probably the FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to pretend it's just another guy on the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FBI. Sure. 'Cause i-if you want to find someone and you're the president, that's who you would call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who else is good at that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The C.I.A.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah, but I was thinking of the Internal Revenue Service. They have computer files that...Well...I should stop stalling. As I'm sure you know, the French have elected themselves a new president, and we're having a formal state dinner at the White House, and I was wondering -- and you're under no obligation at all -- but I thought it might be fun... I was wondering if you maybe wanted to go...with me, and uh... there it is. That's why I was calling. There's a long silence on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney? Sydney, Congress doesn't take this long to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President has asked me to join him in representing our country. I'm honored. I'm equal to the task. And I won't let you down, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, this is just a dinner. We're not gonna be doing espionage or anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Of course. I'm a little...uh...what do I do? I, I mean, where do I go? Should I meet you? Will you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna have a very nice woman named Marsha Bridgeport call you. She's the White House Social Director, and she'll help you with anything you want. Now when she calls you and tells you her name is Marsha Bridgeport, it'll help if you give her the benefit of the doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you Thursday night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, thank you for asking me. Really. This is a first for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. They hang up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large conference room at OEOB has been converted for th use of a half-dozen STAFFERS as well as ten or twelve interns, some of them high school age. A sign on a corkboard reads, "17 Votes in 69 Days." The two numbers are written on two separate pads of paper that the top sheets can be torn off to reveal the followi numbers in descending order. There is also a bulletin board that lists every member of House of Representatives and is divided up into five colu FOR, LEANING TOWARDS, UNDECIDED, LEANING AGAINST, and AGA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's on Indiana? (raising his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me. New people, I can't remember your names. Raise your hand if you're on Indiana. Two INTERNS raise their hands--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Put your hands down -- you're on Illinois. LEWIS comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got Jarrett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George Jarrett. He's ours. Solid "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it. (to an INTERN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. New guy. "Jarrett, Democrat, Minnesota." Slide his name on over to "for." (to Lewis)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just had his name laminated under "Undecided." How'd you get the fence pole out of his butt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish I could take credit. He just said, "Lewis, I support the President a hundred percent ." Not the bill, the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna win this in a walk. It's like a kissing booth at a carnival. Give us a vote, get a photo-op with number 63. LEWIS reaches to the tote board and pulls the "17" off, revealing "16."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should have gone after the handguns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta do one thing at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have time to do one thing at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GDC conference room that SYDNEY, her assistant, DAVID, two INTERNS have made into their 72-day headquarters. A similar tote board reads "23 Votes in 69 Days." The two interns are marking spreadsheets. DAVID is on one phone, SYDNEY is on another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol, it's David in Sydney Wade's office. I want to confirm her lunch with the Congressman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could do with a little party leadership, Mike. Is the Majority Whip takin' a break? Congress is in session, right, I'm not wrong about that? LISA, another intern, is hanging up a phone in the backgr and crossing to the corkboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just got off with Luther Simons. Brock's on board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific! She rips the "23" off, making it "22." SYDNEY reaches for her coffee and knocks over a cup of pencils. In righting pencils, she knocks over her coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're awfully jumpy today. What do you have -- a big date tonight? With that, a big pile of papers is sent flying off the de

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful night. The White House, lit up and shimm in its golden glow, would appear now to be exactly what t poet was looking at when he described The Shining City on Hill. Limousines, several of which fly the flag of foreign diplomats, pull up one by one, their doors opened by whit gloved MARINES. White lights from television cameras mix with the firewor of flashbulbs from the print media.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The GUESTS -- of whom there are a couple hundred -- in bl and evening gowns, are entering the receiving area. All this happening, of course, under the eye of the SECRE SERVICE AGENTS, both American and French, who are strategically placed throughout. The light from a TV camera comes on as a reporter begins quick stand-up interview with ROBERT RUMSON, a handsome m in his late forties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the camera)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm standing here with Senate Minority Leader Robert Rumson, just one of the many guests arriving at what, for a few hours at least, is a non-partisan White House. Senator, the latest public opinion survey shows the President with approval ratings that would make him all but unbeatable, come next November. Is there a Republican who can mount a serious challenge, and are you that candidate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lloyd, it's a long time till next November. Right now, I'm just looking forward to a pleasant evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy is standing behind her father, tying his bow tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a little tight, Luce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be tight. It's supposed to make you look regal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it supposed to cut off the blood flow to my face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All done. He looks in the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad. Where did you learn how to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Social studies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very funny. (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really, where did you learn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...I just guess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie, did Mom teach you how to do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, is this okay with you? My having dinner with a woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's totally okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure? Because if you want to talk about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, it's cool. Go for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm a little nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be fine. Just be yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And compliment her shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her shoes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girls like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dressed in formal, but not festive, clothes and holding, always, her notepad, JANIE waits by the door. A SECRET SERVICE AGENT sits alone behind a small desk. The door opens and SYDNEY walks in. She's, needless to sa stunning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Wade? The President wants you to join him upstairs in the residence. May I show you the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This formal reception area is filled with special GUESTS. SYDNEY walks in, A.J. goes to her immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, come on in. You look beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I have no idea what I'm doing here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you there's no hidden agenda. SHEPHERD approaches SYDNEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney. Andrew Shepherd. We spoke on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I remember. ESTHER, MACINERNERY, A.J.'S wife, joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my wife, Esther.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. It's nice to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (affectionately)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, the President told me about how you two met. I think it's priceless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what happened. One minute I was calling him a mockery of an environmental leader. The next minute I had a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men like being insulted by women. It makes them feel loved. Don't ask me why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, when you meet the French President, don't make him feel too loved, all right? We just signed a new trade agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it. The French President, D'ASTIER, and his WIFE approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to D'Astier)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, would allow me to introduce Sydney Ellen Wade of the Commonwealth of Virginia. Sydney, this is President Rene-Jean D'Astier and his wife Monique Danielle D'Astier of France.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An honor to meet you both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I'm sorry to interrupt. The receiving line is in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, it sounds like our table's ready. SHEPHERD's guests make their way out of the residence, leaving SHEPHERD with SYDNEY and the FRENCH PRESIDENT and MDME. D'ASTIER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD and SYDNEY are walking down the staircase that l to the red-carpeted hall through which the President ente the East Room. The GROUP escorting the President gives them wide berth s that the two of them can have some privacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once we hit the bottom of the stairs, I gotta do a thing. You'll be escorted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took me through it. After a slight pause--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you do this often, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is, actually, only our second State Dinner. The first was for the Emperor of Japan, who died shortly after that, so we stopped having them for a while, just in case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant do you go out on...do you-- often--do you--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I date a lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. How 'bout you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Lately, I seem to be going out on a lot of first dates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're experienced at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, you can ask me anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are we doing so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's hard to say at this point. So far it's just your typical first date stuff. And all of a sudden an INCREDIBLE SOUND from inside the E Room-- --The Marine Corps Brass and Percussion Ensemble plays fo ruffles and flourishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. And I wanted to find a way to be different from the other guys. A BOOMING VOICE over the P.A. announces--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, the President of the United States. And now -- the whole walk timing out with incredible prec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, nice shoes. --SHEPHERD walks into the hall as the Brass and Percussio Ensemble plays HAIL TO THE CHIEF. The 180 GUESTS come to their feet and applaud long and lo The GROUP following the President catches up to the spot where SYDNEY has stopped walking. They all join in the applause. We can see in SYDNEY's face that she's been qui swept up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is beautifully appointed, with the Marine Corps Dance Band playing dinner music -- and the SECRET SERVICE strategically positioned.

dialogues.speaker: AT SHEPHERD'S TABLE
dialogues.text: STEWARDS are clearing away the main course and refilling glasses. In addition to the two main couples, and ESTHER MacINERNE and TWO OTHER COUPLES are seated at the President's table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, the President and Mrs. D'Astier look bored. They're not talking to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're hammered. Esther, do you speak French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Latin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you spoke French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Latin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, next time Julius Caesar comes to town, you're our gal. Sydney, I don't suppose that you speak any--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking over-- to D'Astier)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le President, nous sommes tous habilles, nous avons ce merveilleux orchestre, une piece magnifique...comment se fait-il que les invites ne dansent pas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (proudly to A.J. and Esther)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Je ne connais pas la tradition en Amerique, mais dans mon pays, si les invites de Louis XVI et Marie Antoinette avaient ose danser devant le roi et la reine, ils auraient perdu la tete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, you didn't dissolve the NATO treaty, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just said that we're sitting in this beautiful room, listening to the music of this wonderful orchestra, and I wondered why nobody was dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I informed Ms. Wade that in my country, a guest at the palace of Louis XVI and Marie Antoinette would soon find their head in a guillotine if they made the impertinent gesture of dancing without so much as a by-your-leave from the King and the Queen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet no one accused Louis of being soft on crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a lesson there, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More beheadings at the White House?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob Rumson would embrace it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he would, but I have a better idea. SHEPHERD stands, holds out his hand to SYDNEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, I guess. I mean, yes, sir, I'd love to. SHEPHERD and SYDNEY move to the dance floor, accompanied the appreciative "oooh's" and "ahh's" of the GUESTS. The dance band begins, and SYDNEY and SHEPHERD dance... ...beautifully.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUESTS
dialogues.text: each and every one of them, have stopped all conversation are fixating on this captivating sight. As we go around t room, we can observe the subtle reactions of, at first, various anonymous GUESTS, then

dialogues.speaker: A.J. AND ESTHER MACINERNEY,
dialogues.text: holding hands smiling as they watch their old friend, and

dialogues.speaker: RUMSON'S TABLE
dialogues.text: where the Minority Leader's game face can barely conceal gears that have slowly begun to turn in his head, as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how you do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur Murray. Six lessons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I mean. Two hundred pairs of eyes are focused on you right now, with two questions: "Who's this girl, and why's our president dancing with her?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, the 200 pairs of eyes aren't focused on me. They're focused on you. And the answers are "Sydney Ellen Wade" and "Because she said 'yes.'"

dialogues.speaker: LEWIS AND ROBIN
dialogues.text: looking on from the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make a nice couple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got troubles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge. As PEOPLE start onto dance floor, we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it pulls away from the White House and into the night. the back, SYDNEY slips a shoe off and rubs her foot. She smiles, then turns around to look out the back window the White House slips out of view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. CHAPIL and JANIE are at their respective desks as SHEPHERD walks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mrs. Chapil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. President. Mr. Rothschild and Miss McCall are in the office, sir. They said they needed to speak with you before scheduling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Janie, can you get me the number of a local florist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take care of it, sir. Where do you want them sent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to do it myself. I just need the phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want the phone number of a florist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just want the phone number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, sir, is there--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to send some flowers, Janie. I want to do it myself. I don't want to staff it out, and I don't want to issue an Executive Order. I just want a phone number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get it for you right away, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. He heads into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: where LEWIS and ROBIN are waiting anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, we need five minutes before scheduling if you can spare it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Robin)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just need two minutes to make a call and I'll be right with you. JANIE enters and hands SHEPHERD a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Janie. She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are we calling, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling the Organization of the United Brotherhood of It's-None-of- Your-Damn-Business, Lewis. I'll be with you in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. LEWIS and ROBIN exit the Oval Office. SHEPHERD picks up t phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the OPERATOR)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, good morning. How do I get an outside line? Really? That's simple. Thank you. SHEPHERD dials the phone number JANIE's given him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWIS and ROBIN hovering near the outer office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the President doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm really not at liberty to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something. What is the state flower of Virginia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does this have something to do with Sydney Wade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm really not at liberty to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there someone else there who might know? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not trying to five you a hard time, I was--hold on please.

dialogues.speaker: THE OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD'S VOICE comes through on INTERCOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie, what's the state flower of Virginia?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to MRS. CHAPIL)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Chapil. State flower of Virginia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogwood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogwood, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JANIE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the dogwood. (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Hold on please. (to JANIE, through intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie, the dogwood is a tree, not a flower.

dialogues.speaker: THE OUTER OFFICE
dialogues.text: LEON KODAK walks by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a tree and a flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through intercom)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, it's a tree and a flower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dogwood is both a tree and a flower. I'd like a dozen, please. Really? No dogwoods? How 'bout roses? Simple. Classic. Two dozen roses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie, I'm the President senior domestic policy advisor. It's important that I have a full understanding of--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Janie! Do you have any idea where my credit cards might be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in storage in Wisconsin with the rest of your personal items.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, what might be better is if you just bill me for the flowers. I'm sure it'll be okay with your boss. Well, I don't know if you recognize my voice, but this is the President. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The United States. (they've hung up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo, you wanted to see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there I was, thinking maybe I should give Sydney a call. She's new in town, doesn't know many people... LEO produces a copy of the morning paper, which has a pho of SHEPHERD and SYDNEY dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I picked up the Times--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was crazy. He called me at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing. It was innocent. His cousin got the flu at the last minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
