dialogues.text: Yes, at 20 percent. Three more votes and the President sends it to the Hill. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katie, 10 years from now any cars with an internal combustion engine is gonna be considered a collector's item. Come on board, we'll make your Volvo a classic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWIS and KODAK, each with an AIDE, have been meeting wit two CONGRESSMEN and their AIDES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman, the assault weapons are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bill is priced to move, see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bill isn't the issue, fellas. I'm facing a serious challenge in November, and the President's coattails aren't what they used to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President's coattail's are gonna have room for you, Congressman, you leave that to us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We left that to you people, Leon, and the President's in a free-fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't say he's in a free--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just can't give you my vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEWIS and KODAK stand in front of A.J.'s desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The well is drying up. The President's gotta make a move or we're gonna die fast and quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I do a new poll? We give him detailed public opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we put Sydney in the new model? A.J. hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.J., it's meaningless unless we ask him about Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street's been temporarily closed to traffic, and SECR SERVICE AGENTS man the sidewalk. The PRESS and ONLOOKERS form a small crowd, kept well at bay by police barricades

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD and SYDNEY are finishing up dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was delicious. Thank you. Is there any left?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his bowl)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tons. I didn't think you liked it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me, of course I did. But actually it's not for me. The agent who checked the food thought it was delicious, and I sort of told him I'd bring him some if there was any left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you didn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I loved it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are. I can tell when you're holding something back. You do a thing with your face. SYDNEY pops a bottle of port and pours two glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When have you seen me do a thing with my face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two days before I met you. You gave a speech for the Daughters of the American Revolution. I was there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember the speech?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vaguely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "American can no longer afford to pretend that they live in a great society."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was supposed to be something else after that, wasn't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. The face. SYDNEY hands him a glass. They clink glasses and sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow...what's the occasion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're looking at a lady who's two votes shy of the promised land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two votes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got Pennybaker. That got me Cass and Zimmer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Sydney. I mean it. That's great work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not there yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, no matter what happens, you have every right to be proud of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be proud when I see you sign the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're doing that thing with your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A light rain is falling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KODAK sits at his desk staring at a computer printout. LE is nearing the end of a phone conversation that isn't goi well. He's pacing around with the phone...desperate and intense. The tote board reads: "1 Vote in 2 Days." ROBIN enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to KODAK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're the numbers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty-one. Character across the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is Lewis on with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jarrett. He's trying to keep his finger in the dam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be a United States Congressman, for the love of Christ. ROBIN and KODAK appear in the doorway, sensing a surprise development. LEWIS is losing it on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're not gonna stay at 41. The numbers are gonna be go back up. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're gonna go back up. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congressman Jarrett... (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, it's crunch time. It's personal. This is one of those moments. It's just you and the President. Now that's it gonna be? LEWIS looks over at ROBIN and KODAK ...his face telling t story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (listens)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, George? Can I tell you something? We're gonna win this thing. We're gonna get the votes and we're gonna win. And after we do, I mean that very night, I'm gonna go to Sam & Harry's, I'm gonna order a big steak, and I'm gonna make a list of everybody who tried to fuck us this week. ROBIN and KODAK are trying to get their friend from setti fire to a bridge out of pure frustration. ROBIN (a whispered shout)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vote your conscience, you chicken- shit, lame-ass-- LEWIS hangs up the phone. He takes a deep breath, slumps down in the nearest chair, and looks up at ROBIN and KODA There's a long silence before LEWIS says--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost Jarrett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope so. 'Cause, you know, if that was an "undecided," then we need to work on our people skills. LEWIS picks up the phone and punches in a few numbers. Ev before that line starts ringing, he picks up another phon and punches in a different set of numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the first phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen, it's Lewis. Could you hunt down Congressman Quincy for me. I need to talk to him right way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD stands in front A.J., LEWIS, ROBIN, and KODAK. JANIE is somewhere in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost Quincy, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he give a reason?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He thinks your numbers aren't likely to rebound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're three votes down again, sir. There's a pause before ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, as of this morning, Sydney only needed one more vote. The Motown Three have gotta be scared blind. I don't think there'll be a better opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The press is expecting an announcement on the crime bill by the Sate of the Union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you agree to stick 455 in a drawer until after the elections, they'll give you the three votes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we declare victory, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We said as a last resort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're there, sir. The State of the Union is 48 hours away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Come on. There's gotta be three votes someplace else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, Leon. There's gotta be somebody we haven't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There isn't, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Storch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storch is a "no."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wagner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sobel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that Clark, the one from Indiana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one too, sir. SHEPHERD is stopped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I think we have to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is one vote away, A.J. It's important legislation that for the first time has a legitimate chance. I think she deserves every possible opportunity to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She? You meant "it," didn't you, sir? You meant the "important legislation" deserves every opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, shut up. There's a horrible silence in the room. SHEPHERD has lock eyes with LEWIS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got something to say to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respectfully, sir. I think we should examine the new poll for more than its value as a box score.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Examine what? They don't like that I'm going out with Sydney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that simple, sir. I think this poll helps bribg a murky problem into specific relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose problem we talking about, Lewis? Yours? You worried about your job? This poll isn't talking about my Presidency. This poll is talking about my life. Two hundred and sixty-four million people have decided--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, two hundred and sixty- four million people don't give a damn about your life. They give a damn about their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, you've raised a daughter almost entirely on your own, and she's terrific. What does it say to you that in the last seven weeks, 59 percent of this country has begun to question your family values?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The President doesn't answer to you, Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, he does, A.J.  I'm a citizen, this is my president, and in this country it is not only permissible to question our leaders, it is our responsibility. But you already know that, Mr. President, because you have a deeper love of this country than any man I've ever known, and I want to know what it says to you that in the past seven weeks 59 percent of Americans have begun to question your patriotism?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if people want to listen to Bob Rumson--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have a choice! Rob Rumson's the only one doing the talking. People want leadership. And in the absence of genuine leadership, they will listen to anyone who steps up to the microphone. They want leadership, Mr. President. They're so thirsty for it, they'll crawl through the desert toward a mirage, and when they discover there's no water, they'll drink the sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (evenly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, we've had Presidents who were beloved, who couldn't find a coherent sentence with two hands and a flashlight. People don't drink the sand, 'cause they're thirsty, Lewis. They drink it 'cause they don't know the difference. The room is slightly stunned by what their President has said. SHEPHERD picks up the polling data and heads to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; on his way out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make the deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY, SUSAN, DAVID, INTERNS and STAFFERS are having a little office celebration. Champagne flows from paper cup Streamers and balloons adorn the tote board, which reads Votes in 1 Day. SUSAN, maybe a little drunk, has concerned SYDNEY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go on the record and apologize for my attitude toward you since your arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't notice. Was there an attitude? A PHONE RINGS, and one of the staffers takes it. SYDNEY tries to rejoin the party, but--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I have a lot of pent-up hostility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder who I can blame it on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not really qualified to--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Cause I've been blaming it on my mother and my ex-husband, and that hasn't been working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching SYDNEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo needs to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him to get over here. It's a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs to see you in his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just got off the phone with MacInerney. There's been a development. SYDNEY holds for a moment...then heads out the door and w

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TROMBONE MUSIC comes from LUCY's bedroom as SHEPHERD roun the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD pops his head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's progressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Dad, what's wrong with Sydney? You guys have a fight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She seemed pretty--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your room. Why is she mad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you a dork?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Practice your music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were a dork, you should say you're sorry. Girls like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SYDNEY is going through the closet in search of something The door opens, and SHEPHERD steps in, perhaps a little tentatively. He doesn't see SYDNEY at first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Syd? SYDNEY comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen a gray cableknit sweater?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grey...sweater? No. I called you at the office, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Beth's. I wore it here one time, and I didn't want to leave it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were you going? SYDNEY continues her search.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going home, and then I'm going to Hartford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Connecticut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Do you know if it was sent with your dry cleaning by any--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in Connecticut?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Reynolds' campaign. He may be able to get me a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did you decide to get a new job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long after Leo Solomon fired me from my old one. Beth's gonna kill me. She loves that--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did he fire you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Total failure to achieve any of the objectives for which I was hired. I told him he was being unreasonable. After all, I did get to dance with the President and ride in Air Force One a couple of times. But you know those prickly environmentalists. It's always gonna be something with them. If it's not clean air, then it's clean water. Like it isn't good enough that I'm on the cover of People Magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll call him? You mean you'll call him yourself? Personally? It'll come from the President? That's a great idea. I think you should call Leo and make a deal. He hires me back for, say, 72 days. I go around scaring the hell out of Congress, making them think that the President's about to drive through a very damaging and costly bill. They'll believe me, right, 'cause I'm the President's Friday Night Girl. Now I don't know if you can dip into this well twice, especially since I've lost all credibility in politics, but you never know, I might just be able to pull it off again. I might be able to give you just the leverage you need to pass some ground-breaking piece of crime legislation -- like a mandatory three-day waiting period before a five-year-old can buy an Uzi. Fuck the sweater -- she'll have to learn to live with disappointment. She starts to exit

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think went on here today? She stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know exactly what went on here today. I got screwed. You saw the poll, you needed the crime bill, you couldn't get it on your own, so I got screwed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The environment got screwed. Nothing happened to you today, Sydney. Governing is choosing. Governing is prioritizing. I've made no secret of the fact that the crime bill was my top priority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then, congratulations. It's only taken you three years to put together crime prevention legislation that has no hope of preventing crime. SYDNEY heads out the door--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney. Please. I don't want to lose you over this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, you got bigger problems than losing me. You just lost my vote. And SYDNEY is out the door... ...we HOLD on SHEPHERD, looking like a man who's taken a of punches to the heads...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rack of billiard balls explodes from the break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartfort? What's in Hartford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Reynolds' district office. She's thinking of running his campaign. Four in the corner. SHEPHERD gets down over the ball--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hartford. The insurance capital of the world. Have a good time, Syd. SHEPHERD smacks the ball, BULL'S-EYE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. I'm gonna have Janie clear your schedule for the weekend. You need to get some rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You handling me, A.J.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. 14 in the side. SHEPHERD gets down over the ball...

dialogues.speaker: SMACK
dialogues.text: ...but instead of the cue hitting the ball, it's A.J.'s p slamming the cue against the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I sure as hell will if you don't start gettin' your head outta your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis is right. Go after this guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he lied?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has Rumson lied in the last seven weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has he lied?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Other than not knowing the difference between Harvard and Stanford, has he said something that isn't true? Am I not a Commander-in-Chief who's never served in the military? Am I not opposed to a Constitutional amendment banning flag burning? Am I not an unmarried father who was sharing a bed with a liberal lobbyist down the hall from my twelve-year-old daughter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you think you're wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you win elections by telling 59 percent of the people that they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fight the fights we can win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fight the fights that need fighting!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the view pretty good from the cheap seats, A.J.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It occurs to me that in 25 years I've never seen your name on a ballot. Why have you always been standing a pace behind me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if I hadn't been, you'd be the most popular history professor at the University of Wisconsin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. SHEPHERD's tossed his cue stick and is heading out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have Lewis put the final drafts of the State of the Union and the Crime Bill announcement on my desk in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. SHEPHERD gets to the doorway...stops...turns around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Mary hadn't died...would we have won three years ago?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would we have won?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we'd had to go through a character debate three years ago, would we have won?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. But I would've liked that campaign. If my friend Andy Shepherd had shown up, I would have liked that campaign. SHEPHERD looks away...nods absently...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. SHEPHERD exits, leaving A.J. alone as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of shots showing SHEPHERD walking down the corri to the dish room, then walking down a long corridor which contains a series of paintings of various presidents. The sitting alone in the Oval Office, lost in thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD and LUCY are eating breakfast in silence, neithe them very happy, each with their own problems. A nearby T MONITOR glows with the live coverage of ROBIN's morning p briefing. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not hungry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is oatmeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never have oatmeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from Wisconsin. I need food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not from Wisconsin. I'm from Wisconsin. You've lived in Washington your whole life. He glances toward the T.V. screen. ROBIN's standing up th doing what she's been told: "No comment...No, this Presid is not participating in character debates..." He mutes th volume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing in your Constitutional debates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ratified it last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...well...that's good. Why didn't you tell me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a big deal, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I give up. I don't care why you're not happy in social studies. I care about why you're not talking to me about why you're not happy in social studies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, I'm perfectly--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not perfectly happy. You don't think I know when something's bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit, Dad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look-- LUCY winds herself up. It would appear she's about to bur She's about to say the hardest thing she's ever had to sa her life--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --sometimes when you talk, you say things I disagree with. SHEPHERD is stunned and totally confused...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost every time I talk, I say things you disagree with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean politically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Politically?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean? It just starts spilling out in a stream--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Okay. Yes. Sometimes, I mean, I'm not sure. You know a lot more than I do -- but still, I have these feelings, and I don't think they're wrong. Like, okay, for instance, I'm not so sure it's all right to burn a flag. I mean, it really bothers a lot of people, and I don't know why you think it's okay. I hear Senator Rumson talk, and some of the things he says sounds right to me, and I think, "God, am I like Bob Rumson?! I mean, Dad thinks he's a jerk. Dad hates this guy! Why am I agreeing with him" And then I think, "Well, maybe I'm not really like Bob Rumson, but maybe I'm not like Dad either." But the point is I'm the President's kid, and people pay attention to what I say, and if I say something different from what you say, it'll be embarrassing for you. So I can't just get up in social studies class and say whatever I want. SHEPHERD is silent...totally blown away...he had absolute no idea... He stands up slowly and moves toward her...LUCY doesn't k what's coming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand up please. LUCY gets up slowly... She's never seen her father like this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to pay very close attention to what happens now. SHEPHERD knees down, cups her daughter's face in his hand and gently kisses her forehead. He pulls her to him and holds her in a tight embrace...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your  lifetime, you will never embarrass me. It could never happen. You're not the President's daughter, Lucy, you're mine. And no one's gonna vote me out of that job. You're my daughter, and everything else is a distant second. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School is for you, Lucy. You say what you want. The only thing you have to do to make me happy is come home at the end of the day. LUCY squeezes her dad tight...they hold the embrace for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more thing. I don't dislike Senator Rumson because of his political views. And even if you voted for everything he would vote for, that wouldn't make you like him. There's a fundamental difference between you and the Bob Rumsons of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The difference is that he says he loves America. Saying you love America is easy. What takes character -- and this is what you have-- SHEPHERD trails off, realizing he's about to quote Sydney

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What takes character is loving Americans. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it's as if SHEPHERD is waking himself up from the longest trip of his life... ...he looks over at the T.V. monitor..."No comment"... "No, I don't know how many other ways I can say it. The White House isn't getting involved in..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luce, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad, is everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's fine. I'm just a little late for work. He heads for the door, shouting out as he goes--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody get my daughter some food! The girl's from Wisconsin, for cryin' out loud! And he's gone as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBIN is on her last drops of energy and patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robin, will the President ever respond to Senator Rumson's question about being a member of the American Civil Liberties Union? But instead of hands going up, the PRESS CORPS suddenly stands. ROBIN turns to see SHEPHERD stride in and step up the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, he will. 'Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. President. SHEPHERD takes the podium. There's a palpable BUZZ in the room as video operators adjust their equipment, etc. Peop starts to stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, you can keep your seats. For the last couple of months, Senator Rumson has suggested that being president of this country was, to a certain extent, about character...

dialogues.speaker: ROBIN
dialogues.text: who's picked up the receiver from a wall phone and punche four numbers. She turns in to the wall to shield her conversation from rest of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis...call A.J. and come on down here...I don't know, but something's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and although I have not been willing to engage in his attacks on me, I've been here three years and three days, and I can tell you without hesitation: Being President of this country is entirely about character. LEWIS enters with A.J. and KODAK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the record: Yes, I am a card- carrying member of the A.C.L.U. But the more important question is why aren't you, Bob? This is an organization whose sole purpose is to defend the Bill of Rights, so it naturally begs the questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would a senator, his party's most powerful spokesman and a candidate for president, choose to reject upholding the Constitution? If you can answer that question, then, folks, you're smarter than I am, because I didn't understand it until a couple of minutes ago. Everybody knows American isn't easy. America is advanced citizenship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta want it bad, 'cause it's gonna put up a fight. It's gonna say, "You want free speech? Let's see you acknowledge a man whose words make your blood boil, who's standing center stage and advocating, at the top of his lungs, that which you would spend a lifetime opposing at the top of yours. You want to claim this land as the land of the free, then the symbol of your country can't just be a flag; the symbol also has to be one of its citizens exercising his right to burn that flag in protest." Show me that, defend that, celebrate that in your classrooms. Then you can stand up and sing about the land of the free. I've known Bob Rumson for years. I've been operating under the assumption that the reason Bob devotes so much time and energy to shouting at the rain was that he simply didn't get it. Well, I was wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob's problem isn't that he doesn't get it. Bob's problem is that he can't sell it. Nobody has ever won an election by talking about what I was just talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a country made up of people with hard jobs that they're terrified of losing. The roots of freedom are of little or no interest to them at the moment. We are a nation afraid to go out at night. We're a society that has assigned low priority to education and has looked the other way while our public schools have been decimated. We have serious problems to solve, and we need serious men to solve them. And whatever your particular problem is, friend, I promise you, Bob Rumson is not the least bit interested in solving it. He is interested in two things and two things only: Making you afraid of it and telling you who's to blame for it. That, ladies and gentlemen, is how you win elections. You gather a group of middle-aged, middle-class, middle- income voters who remember with longing an easier time, and you talk to them about family and American values and personal character. Then you have an old photo of the President's girlfriend. You scream about patriotism and you tell them she's to blame for their lot in life, you go on television and you call her a whore. Sydney Ellen Wade has done nothing to you, Bob. She has done nothing but put herself through law school, prosecute criminals for five years, represent the interests of public school teachers for two years, and lobby for the safety of our natural resources.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a character debate? Fine, but you better stick with me, 'cause Sydney Ellen Wade is way out of your league. I've loved two women in my life. I lost one to cancer, and I lost the other 'cause I was so busy keeping my job I forgot to do my job. Well that ends right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning the White House is sending a bill to Congress for its consideration. It's White House Resolution 455, an energy bill requiring a 20 percent reduction of the emission of fossil fuels over the next ten years. It is by far the most aggressive stride ever taken in the fight to reverse the effects of global warming. The other piece of legislation is the crime bill. As of today it no longer exists. I'm throwing it out. I'm throwing it out and writing a law that makes sense. You cannot address crime prevention without getting rid of assault weapons and handguns. I consider them a threat to national security, and I will go door to door if I have to, but I'm gonna convince Americans that I'm right, and I'm gonna get the guns. We've got serous problems, and we need serious men, and if you want to talk about character, Bob, you'd better come at me with more than a burning flag and a membership card. If you want to talk about character and American values, fine. Just tell me where and when, and I'll show up. This is a time for serious men, Bob, and your fifteen minutes are up. My name's Andrew Shepherd, and I am the President. SHEPHERD exits the press room, leaving a stunned room in wake. The MURMURS begin from the PRESS CORPS. They're talking among themselves, confirming that they just saw what they just saw. ROBIN steps to the podium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.J. and LEWIS are following after the President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you don't see that every day of the week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got the whole White House Press Corps asking each other how to spell "erudite."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis, call the printer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Gotta rewrite the State of the Union.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every word, Lewis. It's a whole new ball game. You've got 35 minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, good. I thought I was gonna be rushed. LEWIS goes off in one direction. A.J. heads towards the O Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHEPHERD is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want the limo. I don't want an escort. A.J. enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a plain, ordinary, non- bullet-proof automobile. Someone around here must have a Chevy I can borrow. Well, find one and meet me outside the West Wing entrance in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to her house. I'm gonna stand at her front door till she lets me in. And I'm not leaving till I get her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How're you gonna do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't worked that out yet. But I'm sure groveling will be involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just gonna drive over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the Commander-in-Chief of the most powerful army in the world. You don't think I can drive ten blocks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just stay away from DuPont Circle. I hear it's murder this time of day. SHEPHERD doesn't need to turn around to know who's standi in the doorway, but of course he does anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, A.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nice to see you, Ms. Wade. If anybody needs me, I'll be in the Roosevelt Room, giving Lewis oxygen. A.J. exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard your speech. I was in my car, and it just kind of steered its way over here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad. SYDNEY and SHEPHERD just gaze at each other for a moment smile. SYDNEY starts toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sydney, I didn't decide to send 455 to the floor to get you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't come back 'cause you decided to send 455 to the floor. They move to kiss. It doesn't last very long because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, I thought you might want to look at this. I moved Social Security up front. Hello, Sydney. JANIE enters--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, Leventhal at Treasury wants two minutes. Hello, Sydney. MRS. CHAPIL enters--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President -- Excuse me, Miss Wade -- Miss McCall is on her way over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to SYDNEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some things to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's lit up and glowing on this cold, clear night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're only a moment or two away from the arrival of President Shepherd and his State of the Union address. Lloyd, you've served on the staffs of several past administrations, what kind of last-minute activity is the President engaged in right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's off the main corridor, and it's being used as a gree room for SHEPHERD and his group -- LEWIS, KODAK, A.J., JA and various AIDES and STAFFERS. People are buzzing around a last-minute flurry. SHEPHERD is fumbling with his cuff links.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm having a cuff links crisis. LUCY takes his sleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; to LUCY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think they've locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold still. ROBIN steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President, they're waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lewis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things have been a little rough between us lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know sir, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't stop what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's kind of you, sir, but I realize I've been a little insensitive about some personal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you were right. Two hundred and sixty-four million people don't give a damn about my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just so you know I've never been one of them, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, people. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to LEWIS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you after. The PEOPLE in the room start to gather their things and e ROBIN handling any and all last-minute "Mr. President"'s she herds people out the door. LUCY walks past SHEPHERD. She holds SHEPHERD's old tatter textbook and has it opened to a specific page...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatcha got there, Luce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Article 2, Section 3, of the U.S. Constitution. Executive Powers. (reading)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "He shall, from time to time, give to the Congress information of the State of the Union, and recommend to their consideration such measures as he shall judge necessary and expedient."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds right up your alley. SHEPHERD looks at his old friend and extends his hand for deeply-felt handshake. A.J. grasps SHEPHERD's hand and th pulls him into a strong embrace. A.J. whispers a shout into SHEPHERD's ear--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give 'em hell, Andy. A.J. pulls away, leaving SHEPHERD to enjoy the moment wit having to speak--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got 30 seconds, Mr. President.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to LUCY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you afterward. I want a critique. The room clears out...revealing SYDNEY, dressed like the First Lady she's soon to be, sitting against the window s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's been something I've been trying to give you since our first date. I tried a bunch of times, but somehow I've always managed to trip over my job. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyay... SHEPHERD has picked his black canvas gym bag with the gol Presidential seal. He reaches in the bag and pulls out a bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're beautiful. JANIE pokes her head in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. President?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I stay here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, walk with me. They exit into a hallway lined with Congressional STAFFER SECRET SERVICE, CAPITOL SECURITY, WHITE HOUSE STAFF, and, most prominently, A.J., LEWIS, ROBIN, JANIE and KODAK. SYDNEY is still clutching her flowers as they near the do doors to the House Chamber--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you finally do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his voice above the cheering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manage to give a woman flowers and be President at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...it turns out I've got a rose garden. SYDNEY is stopped in her tracks as-- --the doors to the Chamber fly open--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Speaker!!!...THE PRESIDENT OF THE

dialogues.speaker: UNITED STATES
dialogues.text: The CHAMBER leaps to its feet in a thunderous ovation, shouts of "Bravo!" from the gallery... At the back, LEWIS and ROBIN and KODAK are trying to main their professional cool, but it's a moment impossible not get caught up in...SYDNEY is clutching her flowers with b hands...SHEPHERD is making his way down the aisle, shakin hands and receiving congratulations and good wishes, and FADE OUT.
